citations.narrative:
During a ground transport from Iowa to Washington state, a 10 week old Havanese puppy (MC#991001004597334) died
on March 26, 2024 according to the animal loss record. The facility representative stated that they were stuck in a blizzard
for part of this transport but stated they still checked on the animals every 4 hours. If a puppy falls ill, they check more
often than that. The facility representative stated they do not remember how often they checked this puppy, what it's
symptoms were and what was given to this puppy during the transport, but they stated they likely followed the same
protocol they always do when a puppy starts to get ill during a transport. Per the facility representative: if a puppy
becomes sick or distressed, the drivers should bring the puppy to the front of the van and administer electrolytes and/or
stress drops per a protocol from a broker's attending veterinarian. Once stabilized, the puppies are given a mousse starter
(canned food) and monitored more closely. The transporter has no documentation of the medical care provided to the
animal and this puppy was not seen by a veterinarian during the transport. The facility representative does not remember
when the puppy passed away, but it passed away while in transit. The inspector asked what happens if a puppy does not
respond to supportive care provided by the driver, the facility representative stated they will “force feed” the animal or
sometimes have a veterinarian at a pet store examine the puppy if it is ill at a store drop off on the route. No other
veterinary care is sought out for puppies becoming ill during transport. Failure to obtain veterinary care at the closest
available veterinary facility can lead to physical distress and may have led to this puppy’s death.
The regulated person must ensure that the operator or person accompanying the operator determines whether any of the
dogs or cats are in obvious physical distress and obtains any veterinary care needed for the dogs or cats at the closest
available veterinary facility.
To be corrected: 22-January-2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.18(a)  Critical
   
Care in transit. 
During a ground transport from Iowa to Washington state, a 10 week old Havanese puppy (MC#991001004597334) died 
on March 26, 2024 according to the animal loss record. The facility representative stated that they were stuck in a blizzard 
for part of this transport but stated they still checked on the animals every 4 hours. If a puppy falls ill, they check more 
often than that. The facility representative stated they do not remember how often they checked this puppy, what it's 
symptoms were and what was given to this puppy during the transport, but they stated they likely followed the same 
protocol they always do when a puppy starts to get ill during a transport. Per the facility representative: if a puppy 
becomes sick or distressed, the drivers should bring the puppy to the front of the van and administer electrolytes and/or 
stress drops per a protocol from a broker's attending veterinarian. Once stabilized, the puppies are given a mousse starter 
(canned food) and monitored more closely. The transporter has no documentation of the medical care provided to the 
animal and this puppy was not seen by a veterinarian during the transport. The facility representative does not remember 
when the puppy passed away, but it passed away while in transit. The inspector asked what happens if a puppy does not 
respond to supportive care provided by the driver, the facility representative stated they will “force feed” the animal or 
sometimes have a veterinarian at a pet store examine the puppy if it is ill at a store drop off on the route. No other 
veterinary care is sought out for puppies becoming ill during transport. Failure to obtain veterinary care at the closest 
available veterinary facility can lead to physical distress and may have led to this puppy’s death. 
The regulated person must ensure that the operator or person accompanying the operator determines whether any of the 
dogs or cats are in obvious physical distress and obtains any veterinary care needed for the dogs or cats at the closest 
available veterinary facility. 
To be corrected: 22-January-2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
 n
